explanation:
Correct calculation: The area under section A (a triangle) is \(\frac{1}{2} \times 10\,\text{s} \times 20\,\text{m/s} = 100\,\text{m}\).

Student's error: They likely computed \(\sqrt{10^2 + 20^2} \approx 22.36\), treating the line segment's length as distance. 

Flaw: The student conflated geometric distance (Pythagorean length of the line on the graph) with physical distance (area under the velocity-time curve). 

Connection to misconception: They incorrectly interpreted the graph's diagonal line as requiring spatial measurement via Pythagoras, rather than analyzing time and velocity components to calculate area. 

Distinction: This differs from "distance = speed + time" (arithmetic error) or gradient miscalculations, as the error stems from misapplying geometry to extract physical quantities.
